Stock Market Update

Updated: 24-Jul-19

The market at 10:40 ET

Dow: -64.20...

Nasdaq: +23.24... S&P: +5.19...

NYSE Vol: 153 mln.. Adv: 1800.. Dec: 911

Nasdaq Vol: 487 mln.. Adv: 1719.. Dec: 1095

Moving the Market

Sector Watch

Wall Street climbs off opening lowsRelative strength in UPS (UPS) and the semiconductor stocks following upbeat earnings resultsCaterpillar (CAT), Boeing (BA), and mega-cap tech underperformDoJ launches broad antitrust review of market-leading online platforms

Strong: Industrials, Information Technology, Energy

Weak: Health Care, Utilities

10:40 ET

Dow -64.20 at 27284.99, Nasdaq +23.24 at 8274.65, S&P +5.19 at 3010.66

[BRIEFING.COM] Commodities are higher (+0.5% at 79.92 as measured by the Bloomberg Commodity Index)Dollar index is lower (-0.1% at 97.6160)Looking at energy:Aug WTI crude oil futures are now +$0.75 (+1.3%) at $57.52/barrelEIA petroleum data for the week ended July 19- huge draw in oilCrude oil inventories had a draw of 10.8 mln from the prior weekPrior week showed a draw of 3.1 mlnGasoline Inventories had a draw of 0.2 mln barrelPrior week had a build of 3.6 mln barrelDistillate Inventories had a build of 0.6 mlnPrior week had a build of 5.7 mlnEIA reported U.S. oil production fell 700K barrels per day (bpd) to 11.3 mln bpd, a massive reduction. Recent storm Barry plays some part in the reported data, but this really does seem to be a huge reduction..In other energy, Aug natural gas is -$0.06 (-2.5%) at $2.24/MMBtuMoving on to metals:Aug gold is currently +$2.85 (+0.2%) at $1424.55/oz, while Jul silver is +$0.13 (+0.8%) at $16.61/ozSept copper is now +$0.02 (+0.6%) at $2.72/lb ..NYSE Adv/Dec 1800/911. ..NASDAQ Adv/Dec 1719/1095.

10:00 ET

Dow -80.60 at 27268.59, Nasdaq +3.12 at 8254.53, S&P +0.18 at 3005.65

[BRIEFING.COM] The S&P 500 has marched back to its flat line, while the Russell 2000 trades lower by x%.

Just in, New Home Sales in June hit an annualized rate of 646,000, coming in below the Briefing.com consensus of 660,000. The May reading was revised to 604,000 (from 626,000).

09:45 ET

Dow -139.01 at 27210.18, Nasdaq -6.58 at 8244.83, S&P -2.97 at 3002.5

[BRIEFING.COM] The stock market begins the day modestly lower amid weakness in Caterpillar (CAT 129.24, -8.89, -6.4%), Boeing (BA 367.44, -5.80, -1.6%), and mega-cap tech stocks. The S&P 500 is down 0.1%, the Dow Jones Industrial Average is down 0.5%, and the Nasdaq composite is down 0.1%.

An early look at the S&P 500 sectors shows industrials (-0.1%) recovering some its opening losses as UPS (UPS 114.00, +8.71, +8.0%) helps offset losses from Caterpillar and Boeing following their earnings reports. Health care (-0.9%) is an early laggard, while energy (+0.4%) outperforms.

Separately, Facebook (FB 199.30, -3.09, -1.5%), Alphabet (GOOG 1131.90, -14.31, -1.3%), and Amazon (AMZN 1974.59, -19.90, -1.0%) are each down at least 1.0% after the DoJ launched an antitrust probe into the leading online platforms.

U.S. Treasuries are slightly higher, pushing yields lower. The 2-yr yield and the 10-yr yield are down two basis points each to 1.81% and 2.05%, respectively. The U.S. Dollar Index is down 0.1% to 97.63. WTI crude is up 0.3% to $56.91/bbl.

09:15 ET

Market is Closed

[BRIEFING.COM] S&P futures vs fair value: -7.60. Nasdaq futures vs fair value: -24.50.

Wall Street is headed for a lower start in a busy morning in news that has reined in some of yesterday's enthusiasm. The S&P 500 futures trade eight points, or 0.3%, below fair value.

Alphabet (GOOG 1134.35, -11.86, -1.0%), Amazon (AMZN 1970.00, -24.49, -1.2%), and Facebook (FB 198.50, -3.86, -1.9%) are under pressure this morning after the DoJ announced that it will conduct a broad antitrust review of market-leading online platforms. On a related note, the FTC confirmed that Facebook will pay $5 billion for its privacy mishaps.

Elsewhere, shares of Caterpillar (CAT 131.20, -6.60, -4.8%) are getting hit in pre-market after the Dow component missed earnings estimates and lowered its full-year EPS guidance. Fellow Dow components Visa (V 180.21, -0.69, -0.4%) and Boeing (BA 370.89, -2.18, -0.6%) are also down following their results.

Overseas, the slowdown in the eurozone region has persisted, evidenced by the weaker-than-expected flash Manufacturing PMI readings for July. The eurozone reading declined to 46.4 from 47.6. A level below 50.0 denotes a contraction.

08:50 ET

Market is Closed

[BRIEFING.COM] S&P futures vs fair value: -7.10. Nasdaq futures vs fair value: -20.40.

The S&P 500 futures trade seven points, or 0.2%, below fair value.

Equity indices in the Asia-Pacific region ended the midweek session on a mixed note. People's Bank of China Governor, Yi Gang, said that the central bank does not intend to follow the Fed with a rate cut of its own. Meanwhile, Westpac expects that the Reserve Bank of Australia will lower its cash rate in October and February. Japan threatened to remove South Korea from a list of countries that face minimum export restrictions. Nissan will reportedly fire more than 10,000 workers.

In economic data: Japan's May Leading Index 94.9 (expected 95.2; last 95.9) and flash July Manufacturing PMI 49.6 (expected 49.7; last 49.3). Australia's flash July Manufacturing PMI 51.4 (last 52.0) and flash Services PMI 51.9 (last 52.6). New Zealand's June trade surplus NZD365 mln (expected surplus of NZD100 mln; last surplus of NZD175 mln).

---Equity Markets---

Japan's Nikkei: +0.4% Hong Kong's Hang Seng: +0.2% China's Shanghai Composite: +0.8% India's Sensex: -0.4% South Korea's Kospi: -0.9% Australia's ASX All Ordinaries: +0.7%

Major European indices are mixed. The latest flash Manufacturing PMI readings from France and Germany showed another decrease with Germany's flash Manufacturing PMI sliding to 43.1, a level not seen since the summer of 2012 when the region was grappling with a financial crisis. Incoming British Prime Minister Boris Johnson said that all members of his cabinet must allow for the possibility of a no-deal Brexit. Deutsche Bank is down 2.5% after reporting its largest loss in eleven years.

In economic data: Eurozone's flash July Manufacturing PMI 46.4 (expected 47.6; last 47.6) and flash Services PMI 53.3, as expected (last 53.6). June M3 Money Supply +4.5% yr/yr (expected 4.6%; last 4.8%) and Private Sector Loans +3.3% yr/yr (expected 3.2%; last 3.3%). Germany's flash July Manufacturing PMI 43.1 (expected 45.1; last 45.0) and flash Services PMI 55.4 (expected 55.3; last 55.8). France's flash July Manufacturing PMI 50.0 (expected 51.6; last 51.9) and Services PMI 52.2 (expected 52.7; last 52.9). July Business Survey 101 (expected 102; last 102). Swiss July ZEW Expectations -24.0 (last -30.0)

---Equity Markets---

STOXX Europe 600: -0.1%Germany's DAX: +0.3% U.K.'s FTSE 100: -0.8% France's CAC 40: -0.4% Italy's FTSE MIB: +0.3% Spain's IBEX 35: +0.3%

08:29 ET

Market is Closed

[BRIEFING.COM] S&P futures vs fair value: -6.40. Nasdaq futures vs fair value: -16.30.

The S&P 500 futures trade six points, or 0.2%, below fair value.

Treasury Secretary Mnuchin recently had wide-ranging interview with CNBC. Regarding the planned trade talks with China, he said he will depart for Beijing with USTR Lighthizer on Monday, and negotiations will be held on Tuesday and Wednesday. Separately, he said the DoJ should look into Amazon's (AMZN 1973.00, -21.49, -1.1%) practices.

In other earnings news, ChipotleMexican Grill (CMG 762.34, +22.74, +3.1%) and Snap (SNAP 16.48, +1.65, +11.3%) have impressed investors with upbeat results and guidance. Telsey Advisory Group and Maxim Group raised their CMG price targets to $750 and $670, respectively. Snap was upgraded to Neutral from Sell at UBS and Buy from Hold at Summit Insights.

08:00 ET

Market is Closed

[BRIEFING.COM] S&P futures vs fair value: -7.90. Nasdaq futures vs fair value: -17.90.

U.S. equity futures have been weighed down this morning by the big technology stocks amid continued regulatory scrutiny. The S&P 500 futures trade eight points, or 0.3%, below fair value.

The Department of Justice announced yesterday that it will conduct a broad antitrust review of the "market-leading online platforms." Big tech scrutiny is nothing new, but the latest action confirms serious efforts to check the influence of big tech companies. The regulatory overhang has weighed on shares of Alphabet (GOOG 1134.00, -12.21, -1.1%), Facebook (FB 199.55, -2.81, -1.4%), and Amazon (AMZN 1976.60, -17.89, -0.9%) in pre-market action.

In earnings news, Dow components Visa (V 180.20, -0.70, -0.4%), Boeing (BA 370.50, -2.57, -0.7%), and Caterpillar (CAT 133.49, -4.61, -3.3%) were some blue-chip companies to report since yesterday's close. Shares of Caterpillar are getting hit following disappointing results and guidance, while shares of Boeing slip after the company continues to not provide full-year guidance.

Elsewhere, the eurozone flash July Manufacturing PMI declined below expectations, coming in at 46.4, amid weakness in Germany. A reading below 50.0 denotes a contraction. In U.S. data, investors will receive New Home Sales for June (Briefing.com consensus 660,000) at 10:00 a.m. ET. The weekly MBA Mortgage Applications Index declined 1.9% following a 1.1% decline in the prior week.

U.S. Treasuries haven't reflected too much concern about the eurozone slowdown, as yields are little changed. The 2-yr yield is down two basis points to 1.81%, and the 10-yr yield is down one basis point to 2.06%. The U.S. Dollar Index is down 0.1% to 97.61. WTI crude is up 0.4% to $56.99/bbl.

In U.S. Corporate news:

Boeing (BA 370.50, -2.57): -0.7% despite beating top and bottom-line estimates. Boeing reported an EPS loss, which was expected, but the company continues to not provide full-year guidance. Caterpillar (CAT 133.49, -4.61): -3.3% after missing earnings expectations and lowering its FY19 EPS guidance. Visa (V 180.20, -0.70): -0.4% despite beating top and bottom-line estimates and slightly raising its FY19 EPS guidance. Texas Instruments (TXN 126.33, +6.26): +5.2% after beating top and bottom-line estimates. AT&T (T 31.53, -0.56): -1.8% despite releasing in-line results and raising its free cash flow guidance. UPS (UPS 108.00, +2.73): +2.6% after beating profit expectations.

Reviewing overnight developments:

Equity indices in the Asia-Pacific region ended the midweek session on a mixed note. Japan's Nikkei +0.4%, Hong Kong's Hang Seng +0.2%, China's Shanghai Composite +0.8%, India's Sensex -0.4%, South Korea's Kospi -0.9%, Australia's ASX All Ordinaries +0.7%.In economic data:Japan's May Leading Index 94.9 (expected 95.2; last 95.9) and flash July Manufacturing PMI 49.6 (expected 49.7; last 49.3).Australia's flash July Manufacturing PMI 51.4 (last 52.0) and flash Services PMI 51.9 (last 52.6).New Zealand's June trade surplus NZD365 mln (expected surplus of NZD100 mln; last surplus of NZD175 mln).In news: People's Bank of China Governor, Yi Gang, said that the central bank does not intend to follow the Fed with a rate cut of its own.Meanwhile, Westpac expects that the Reserve Bank of Australia will lower its cash rate in October and February. Japan threatened to remove South Korea from a list of countries that face minimum export restrictions. Nissan will reportedly fire more than 10,000 workers.Major European indices are mixed. STOXX Europe 600 UNCH, Germany's DAX +0.4%, U.K.'s FTSE 100 -1.0%, France's CAC 40 -0.3%, Italy's FTSE MIB +0.4%, Spain's IBEX 35 +0.3%.In economic data:Eurozone's flash July Manufacturing PMI 46.4 (expected 47.6; last 47.6) and flash Services PMI 53.3, as expected (last 53.6). July Business Survey 101 (expected 102; last 102).Swiss July ZEW Expectations -24.0 (last -30.0)In news:The latest flash Manufacturing PMI readings from France and Germany showed another decrease with Germany's flash Manufacturing PMI sliding to 43.1, a level not seen since the summer of 2012 when the region was grappling with a financial crisis. Incoming British Prime Minister Boris Johnson said that all members of his cabinet must allow for the possibility of a no-deal Brexit.Deutsche Bank is down 2.5% after reporting its largest loss in eleven years.

16:15 ET

Dow +177.29 at 27349.19, Nasdaq +47.27 at 8251.41, S&P +20.44 at 3005.47

[BRIEFING.COM] The S&P 500 increased 0.7% on Tuesday, bolstered by encouraging trade news and positive earnings reports from widely-held companies. The Dow Jones Industrial Average (+0.7%), Nasdaq Composite (+0.6%), and Russell 2000 (+0.7%) advanced in-line with the benchmark index.

It had been a tight-ranged session for a good part of the day despite positive earnings results and guidance from a diversified group of companies like Coca-Cola (KO 54.33, +3.11, +6.1%), United Technologies (UTX 134.94, +1.99, +1.5%), Sherwin-Williams (SHW 490.23, +35.64, +7.8%), and Biogen (BIIB 243.88, +11.40, +4.9%). Travelers (TRV 147.50, -2.21, -1.5%), however, did come up short of expectations.

Unsurprisingly, a positive trade headline helped energize the slow-moving market. Bloomberg reported that USTR Lighthizer and other senior officials will head to China next week to continue trade talks from Monday to Wednesday. Although this possibility had been reported earlier and many high-level talks in the past have yielded little progress, the good mood in the market flowing from earnings seemed to sway the market.

The news pushed the S&P 500 back above the 3000 level, where it would stay above on a closing basis. Ten of the 11 S&P 500 sectors finished higher, led by the trade-sensitive materials (+2.0%) and industrials (+1.2%) sectors. The utilities sector was the lone holdout, finishing lower by 0.6%.

Qualcomm (QCOM 74.12, -1.83, -2.4%) was also left out of the advance after The Wall Street Journal reported that Apple (AAPL 208.84, +1.62, +0.8%) is considering buying Intel's (INTC 51.75, +0.40, +0.8%) smartphone-modem chip business for around $1 billion. The Philadelphia Semiconductor Index finished up 1.2%.

Separately, Congress reached a deal to increase the budget deficit and suspend the debt ceiling for two years. The news provided some relief for investors, but market reaction was mostly muted as the dilemma never appeared to hinder the market beforehand and it was reported yesterday that a deal was close.

U.S. Treasuries finished on a lower note, pushing yields higher across the curve. The 2-yr yield increased two basis points to 1.83%, and the 10-yr yield increased three basis points to 2.07%. The U.S. Dollar Index advanced 0.5% to 97.74, helped by some weakness in the euro. WTI crude rose 0.9% to $56.72/bbl.

Reviewing Tuesday's economic data, which included Existing Home Sales for June and the FHFA Housing Market Index for May:

Existing home sales decreased 1.7% month-over-month in June to a seasonally-adjusted annual rate of 5.27 million (Briefing.com consensus 5.30 million) from an upwardly revised 5.36 million (from 5.34 million) in May. Total sales were 2.2% lower than the same period a year ago.The key takeaway from the report is that the drop in mortgage rates has failed to spur a meaningful pickup in existing home sales, which continue to be constrained by the lack of available supply at lower price points.The FHFA Housing Price Index for May increased 0.1% after advancing 0.4% in June.

Looking ahead, investors will receive New Home Sales for June and the weekly MBA Mortgage Applications Index on Wednesday.

Stock Market Update

Updated: 27-Jul-20

The market at 10:55 ET

Dow: +134.52...

Nasdaq: +122.97... S&P: +20.07...

NYSE Vol: 212.0 mln.. Adv: 1684.. Dec: 1155

Nasdaq Vol: 1.4 bln.. Adv: 1967.. Dec: 1214

Moving the Market

Sector Watch

-- Mega-caps lifts market higher in front of busy news week-- U.S. dollar continues to weaken, gold futures keep rallying -- Investors await coronavirus relief bill later today

Strong: Information Technology, Consumer Discretionary, Communication Services, Materials

Weak: Financials, Energy, Utilities

10:55 ET

Dow +134.52 at 26604.41, Nasdaq +122.97 at 10486.23, S&P +20.07 at 3235.7

[BRIEFING.COM] The S&P 500 continues to trade near session highs with a 0.6% gain. Today's advance comes in front of a jam-packed week of news.

Later today, Republicans are expected to unveil a $1 trillion coronavirus relief bill, so stay tuned for that. On Wednesday, the FOMC will release its latest policy directive and CEOs from some of the largest tech companies will testify before Congress regarding antitrust concerns.

Apple (AAPL 377.36, +6.87, +1.8%), Amazon (AMZN 3065.75, +56.84, +1.9%), and Alphabet (GOOG 1529.04, +17.17, +1.1%) will then report earnings after Thursday's close.

10:25 ET

Dow +136.82 at 26606.71, Nasdaq +118.71 at 10481.97, S&P +18.93 at 3234.56

[BRIEFING.COM] The S&P 500 continues to trade higher by 0.6%, while the Russell 2000 trades higher by 0.5%.

In corporate news, Moderna (MRNA 77.40, +4.19, +5.7%) announced it will receive an additional $472 million from the Biomedical Advanced Research and Development Authority (BARDA) to develop its COVID-19 vaccine candidate. MRNA shares are up 5%.

Separately, shares of Hasbro (HAS 72.55, -5.04, -6.5%) are down 6.5% after the company missed top and bottom-line estimates.

10:00 ET

Dow +106.38 at 26576.27, Nasdaq +135.54 at 10498.8, S&P +18.20 at 3233.83

[BRIEFING.COM] The S&P 500 is now up 0.6%, as the materials (+1.2%) and health care (+0.5%) sectors join the the mega-cap rally.

Apple (AAPL 377.94, +7.49, +2.0%) and Amazon (AMZN 3081.12, +73.98, +2.4%) are up 2.0% after the stocks spent the last two weeks in consolidation mode. On a related note, AAPL had its price target raised to $425 from $365 at JP Morgan, and AMZN had its price target raised to $3600 from $2800 at Telsey Advisory Group.

Separately, shares of Walgreens Boots Alliance (WBA 39.63, -0.88, -2.1%) are down 2% amid news that CEO Stefano Pessina will step down from the helm.

09:40 ET

Dow -30.93 at 26438.96, Nasdaq +93.21 at 10456.47, S&P +3.31 at 3218.94

[BRIEFING.COM] The major indices start the day mixed, with the Nasdaq Composite outperforming with a 0.9% gain. The S&P 500 is up 0.1%, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average is down 0.1%.

Looking at the S&P 500 sectors shows mixed results. The information technology (+0.7%), consumer discretionary (+0.6%), and communication services (+0.4%) sectors are among the early leaders amid relative strength in the mega-caps, while the financials (-1.2%) and energy (-1.1%) sectors are down more than 1.0%.

U.S. Treasuries trade near their flat lines. The 2-yr yield is flat at 0.14%, and the 10-yr yield is flat at 0.58%. Gold futures ($1928.30, +30.80, +1.7%) are trading above $1900/ozt, benefiting from a weak dollar (93.77, -0.67, -0.7%). WTI crude is down 0.9% to $40.93/bbl.

09:12 ET

Market is Closed

[BRIEFING.COM] S&P futures vs fair value: +10.60. Nasdaq futures vs fair value: +83.00.

The stock market is headed for a slightly higher start, as the S&P 500 futures trade 11 points, or 0.3%, above fair value ahead of an eventful week.

Apple (AAPL 374.94, +4.48, +1.2%), Amazon (AMZN 3063.98, +55.07, +1.8%), and Alphabet (GOOG 1524.00, +12.13, +0.8%) outperform in pre-market action ahead of their earnings reports on Thursday. There will be plenty of action before Thursday, though.

Senate Republicans are expected to unveil a $1 trillion coronavirus relief bill today, the FOMC will begin a two-day policy meeting on Tuesday, and the CEOs to some of the largest tech companies will head to Capitol Hill on Wednesday to address regulatory concerns.

08:51 ET

Market is Closed

[BRIEFING.COM] S&P futures vs fair value: +7.90. Nasdaq futures vs fair value: +67.50.

The S&P 500 futures trade eight points, or 0.3%, above fair value.

Equity indices in the Asia-Pacific region began the week on a mixed note. U.S. officials entered the Chinese consulate in Houston shortly after the passage of Friday's deadline that was given to the Chinese diplomatic mission. China responded by seizing the U.S. consulate in Chengdu this morning. Reserve Bank of Australia Assistant Governor, Christopher Kent, said that the RBA is not considering new policy measures at this time.

In economic data: China's June Industrial Profit -12.8% YTD (last -19.3%) Japan's May Leading Index 78.4 (expected 79.3; last 77.7) and Coincident Indicator -6.7% m/m (last -5.5%) Hong Kong's June trade deficit HKD33.30 bln (last deficit of HKD13.70 bln). June Imports -7.1% m/m (last -12.3%) and Exports -1.3% m/m (last -7.4%)

---Equity Markets---

Japan's Nikkei: -0.2% Hong Kong's Hang Seng: -0.4% China's Shanghai Composite: +0.3% India's Sensex: -0.5% South Korea's Kospi: +0.8% Australia's ASX All Ordinaries: +0.4%

Major European indices trade in negative territory. Italy's Economy Minister, Roberto Gualtieri, reportedly warned about the potential for a funding crisis in the fall if states do not receive immediate access to loans. Bundesbank President, Jens Weidmann, said that using mutualized debt to help weaker states should be an exception. Fitch affirmed Greece's BB rating and the ESM's AAA rating.

In economic data: Eurozone's June loans to non-financial corporations 7.1% yr/yr (last 7.3%) and M3 Money Supply 9.2% yr/yr (expected 9.3%; last 8.9%) Germany's July ifo Business Climate Index 90.5 (expected 89.3; last 86.3). July Current Assessment 84.5 (expected 85.0; last 81.3) and Business Expectations 97.0 (expected 93.7; last 91.6) France's June jobseeker total 3.96 mln (last 4.17 mln)

08:32 ET

Market is Closed

[BRIEFING.COM] S&P futures vs fair value: +12.60. Nasdaq futures vs fair value: +81.10.

The S&P 500 futures trade 13 points, or 0.4%, above fair value.

Durable goods orders increased 7.3% in June (Briefing.com consensus +6.4%), and the prior month's increase was revised to 15.1% (from 15.8%). Excluding transportation, durable orders increased 3.3% (Briefing.com consensus +3.3%) to follow the prior month's revised 3.6% increase (from 4.0%).

07:56 ET

Market is Closed

[BRIEFING.COM] S&P futures vs fair value: +14.90. Nasdaq futures vs fair value: +99.60.

The S&P 500 futures trade 15 points, or 0.5%, above fair value to start the week, as investors await the coronavirus relief bill negotiated by the White House and Senate Republicans.

Reports indicate the bill will cost about $1 trillion, significantly less than what Democrats want, while Politico reported that GOP lawmakers intend on releasing the bill around 4:30 p.m. ET today, which would be after today's close. Related headlines could be announced throughout the day.

Separately, the mega-cap technology stocks are providing solid support for the futures trade after two straight weeks of mega-cap consolidation. On a related note, several of these big tech CEOs will testify before Congress on Wednesday regarding antitrust concerns.

On the data front, investors will receive Durable Goods Orders for June (Briefing.com consensus 6.4%) at 8:30 a.m. ET.

U.S. Treasuries trade little changed, while precious metals have extended their recent rally amid continued weakness in the dollar (93.78, -0.66, -0.7%). Gold futures are up 2.1% to $1937.40/ozt. The 2-yr yield is up one basis point to 0.15%, and the 10-yr yield is flat at 0.58%. WTI crude is up 0.3% to $41.43/bbl.

In U.S. Corporate news:

Moderna (MRNA 79.37, +6.16): +8.4% after being awarded up to $472 million from the Biomedical Advanced Research and Development Authority (BARDA) to develop its COVID-19 vaccine candidate.Amazon (AMZN 3059.00, +50.09): +1.7% amid today's mega-cap gains. On a related note, Telsey Advisory Group raised its AMZN price target to $3600 from $2800.Hasbro (HAS 74.00, -3.59): -4.6% after missing top and bottom-line estimates.

Reviewing overnight developments:

Equity indices in the Asia-Pacific region began the week on a mixed note. Japan's Nikkei: -0.2%, Hong Kong's Hang Seng: -0.4%, China's Shanghai Composite: +0.3%, India's Sensex: -0.5%, South Korea's Kospi: +0.8%, Australia's ASX All Ordinaries: +0.4%.In economic data:China's June Industrial Profit -12.8% YTD (last -19.3%)Japan's May Leading Index 78.4 (expected 79.3; last 77.7) and Coincident Indicator -6.7% m/m (last -5.5%)Hong Kong's June trade deficit HKD33.30 bln (last deficit of HKD13.70 bln). July Current Assessment 84.5 (expected 85.0; last 81.3) and Business Expectations 97.0 (expected 93.7; last 91.6)France's June jobseeker total 3.96 mln (last 4.17 mln)In news:Italy's Economy Minister, Roberto Gualtieri, reportedly warned about the potential for a funding crisis in the fall if states do not receive immediate access to loans. Bundesbank President, Jens Weidmann, said that using mutualized debt to help weaker states should be an exception. Fitch affirmed Greece's BB rating and the ESM's AAA rating.

07:00 ET

16:20 ET

Dow -182.44 at 26469.89, Nasdaq -98.24 at 10363.26, S&P -20.03 at 3215.63

[BRIEFING.COM] The stock market ended the week in negative territory in a mostly broad-based decline. The S&P 500 fell 0.6%, the Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.7%, and the Nasdaq Composite fell 0.9%. The small-cap Russell 2000 underperformed with a 1.5% decline.

Ten of the 11 S&P 500 sectors closed lower, but the health care (-1.1%) and information technology (-1.2%) sectors were the only sectors to decline more than 1.0%. Note, the tech sector was down as much as 2.7% intraday, while the consumer discretionary sector gained 0.3% as shares of Amazon (AMZN 3008.91, +22.36, +0.8%) recovered an early 3.3% decline.

Intel (INTC 50.59, -9.81, -16.2%) did very little recovering, with shares falling 16% after the company announced a six-month delay in its next-generation 7nm chip technology. While disappointing for Intel investors, the news was welcomed by investors of Advanced Micro Devices (AMD 69.40, +9.83, +16.5%).

Other negative factors today included China ordering the U.S. to close its consulate in Chengdu in response to the U.S. ordering China to close its consulate in Houston and a delay in the Republican coronavirus relief bill until next week.

On a more positive note, new home sales surged 13.8% m/m in June to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 776,000 (Briefing.com consensus 680,000). That was the strongest pace of sales since July 2007 and higher than the pre-pandemic pace of 774,000 seen in January.

In other corporate news, Goldman Sachs (GS 201.47, -1.66, -0.8%) settled its 1MDB case for $3.9 billion, Verizon (VZ 56.85, +1.00, +1.8%) beat top and bottom-line estimates, American Express (AXP 95.33, -1.34, -1.4%) reported mixed quarterly results, and Walt Disney (DIS 117.61, -0.51, -0.4%) reportedly delayed several blockbuster movies by a year.

U.S. Treasuries finished little changed. The 2-yr yield declined one basis point to 0.14%, and the 10-yr yield was flat at 0.58%. Gold futures rose 0.4% to $1897.50/ozt -- its highest settlement price ever amid continued weakness in the U.S. Dollar Index (94.39, -0.30, -0.3%). WTI crude futures settled little changed at $41.08/bbl.

Reviewing Friday's economic data:

New home sales surged 13.8% m/m in June to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 776,000 (Briefing.com consensus 680,000). That was the strongest pace of sales since July 2007 and higher than the pre-pandemic pace of 774,000 seen in January. On a yr/yr basis, new home sales were up 13.7%.The key takeaway from the report is that sales activity in the new home market is quite healthy given the tight supply of existing homes for sale, low mortgage rates, pent-up demand, and an emerging, coronavirus-driven shift by city dwellers to suburban settings.

Looking ahead, investors will receive Durable Goods Orders for June on Monday.

urn:contentItem:60FN-SV41-JC8H-K05N-00000-00Briefing.com: Stock Market Update - 10:55 ET2020-07-27T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:29:47ZLexisNexisBriefing.com: Stock Market Update - 10:55 ET

Stock Market Update

Updated: 27-Jul-20

The market at 10:55 ET

Dow: +134.52...

Nasdaq: +122.97... S&P: +20.07...

NYSE Vol: 212.0 mln.. Adv: 1684.. Dec: 1155

Nasdaq Vol: 1.4 bln.. Adv: 1967.. Dec: 1214

Moving the Market

Sector Watch

-- Mega-caps lifts market higher in front of busy news week-- U.S. dollar continues to weaken, gold futures keep rallying -- Strength in semiconductor space-- Investors await coronavirus relief bill later today

Strong: Information Technology, Consumer Discretionary, Communication Services, Materials

Weak: Financials, Energy, Utilities

10:55 ET

Dow +134.52 at 26604.41, Nasdaq +122.97 at 10486.23, S&P +20.07 at 3235.7

[BRIEFING.COM] The S&P 500 continues to trade near session highs with a 0.6% gain. Today's advance comes in front of a jam-packed week of news.

Later today, Republicans are expected to unveil a $1 trillion coronavirus relief bill, so stay tuned for that. On Wednesday, the FOMC will release its latest policy directive and CEOs from some of the largest tech companies will testify before Congress regarding antitrust concerns.

Apple (AAPL 377.36, +6.87, +1.8%), Amazon (AMZN 3065.75, +56.84, +1.9%), and Alphabet (GOOG 1529.04, +17.17, +1.1%) will then report earnings after Thursday's close.

10:25 ET

Dow +136.82 at 26606.71, Nasdaq +118.71 at 10481.97, S&P +18.93 at 3234.56

[BRIEFING.COM] The S&P 500 continues to trade higher by 0.6%, while the Russell 2000 trades higher by 0.5%.

In corporate news, Moderna (MRNA 77.40, +4.19, +5.7%) announced it will receive an additional $472 million from the Biomedical Advanced Research and Development Authority (BARDA) to develop its COVID-19 vaccine candidate. MRNA shares are up 5%.

Separately, shares of Hasbro (HAS 72.55, -5.04, -6.5%) are down 6.5% after the company missed top and bottom-line estimates.

10:00 ET

Dow +106.38 at 26576.27, Nasdaq +135.54 at 10498.8, S&P +18.20 at 3233.83

[BRIEFING.COM] The S&P 500 is now up 0.6%, as the materials (+1.2%) and health care (+0.5%) sectors join the the mega-cap rally.

Apple (AAPL 377.94, +7.49, +2.0%) and Amazon (AMZN 3081.12, +73.98, +2.4%) are up 2.0% after the stocks spent the last two weeks in consolidation mode. On a related note, AAPL had its price target raised to $425 from $365 at JP Morgan, and AMZN had its price target raised to $3600 from $2800 at Telsey Advisory Group.

Separately, shares of Walgreens Boots Alliance (WBA 39.63, -0.88, -2.1%) are down 2% amid news that CEO Stefano Pessina will step down from the helm.

09:40 ET

Dow -30.93 at 26438.96, Nasdaq +93.21 at 10456.47, S&P +3.31 at 3218.94

[BRIEFING.COM] The major indices start the day mixed, with the Nasdaq Composite outperforming with a 0.9% gain. The S&P 500 is up 0.1%, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average is down 0.1%.

Looking at the S&P 500 sectors shows mixed results. The information technology (+0.7%), consumer discretionary (+0.6%), and communication services (+0.4%) sectors are among the early leaders amid relative strength in the mega-caps, while the financials (-1.2%) and energy (-1.1%) sectors are down more than 1.0%.

U.S. Treasuries trade near their flat lines. The 2-yr yield is flat at 0.14%, and the 10-yr yield is flat at 0.58%. Gold futures ($1928.30, +30.80, +1.7%) are trading above $1900/ozt, benefiting from a weak dollar (93.77, -0.67, -0.7%). WTI crude is down 0.9% to $40.93/bbl.

09:12 ET

Market is Closed

[BRIEFING.COM] S&P futures vs fair value: +10.60. Nasdaq futures vs fair value: +83.00.

The stock market is headed for a slightly higher start, as the S&P 500 futures trade 11 points, or 0.3%, above fair value ahead of an eventful week.

Apple (AAPL 374.94, +4.48, +1.2%), Amazon (AMZN 3063.98, +55.07, +1.8%), and Alphabet (GOOG 1524.00, +12.13, +0.8%) outperform in pre-market action ahead of their earnings reports on Thursday. There will be plenty of action before Thursday, though.

Senate Republicans are expected to unveil a $1 trillion coronavirus relief bill today, the FOMC will begin a two-day policy meeting on Tuesday, and the CEOs to some of the largest tech companies will head to Capitol Hill on Wednesday to address regulatory concerns.

08:51 ET

Market is Closed

[BRIEFING.COM] S&P futures vs fair value: +7.90. Nasdaq futures vs fair value: +67.50.

The S&P 500 futures trade eight points, or 0.3%, above fair value.

Equity indices in the Asia-Pacific region began the week on a mixed note. U.S. officials entered the Chinese consulate in Houston shortly after the passage of Friday's deadline that was given to the Chinese diplomatic mission. China responded by seizing the U.S. consulate in Chengdu this morning. Reserve Bank of Australia Assistant Governor, Christopher Kent, said that the RBA is not considering new policy measures at this time.

In economic data: China's June Industrial Profit -12.8% YTD (last -19.3%) Japan's May Leading Index 78.4 (expected 79.3; last 77.7) and Coincident Indicator -6.7% m/m (last -5.5%) Hong Kong's June trade deficit HKD33.30 bln (last deficit of HKD13.70 bln). June Imports -7.1% m/m (last -12.3%) and Exports -1.3% m/m (last -7.4%)

---Equity Markets---

Japan's Nikkei: -0.2% Hong Kong's Hang Seng: -0.4% China's Shanghai Composite: +0.3% India's Sensex: -0.5% South Korea's Kospi: +0.8% Australia's ASX All Ordinaries: +0.4%

Major European indices trade in negative territory. Italy's Economy Minister, Roberto Gualtieri, reportedly warned about the potential for a funding crisis in the fall if states do not receive immediate access to loans. Bundesbank President, Jens Weidmann, said that using mutualized debt to help weaker states should be an exception. Fitch affirmed Greece's BB rating and the ESM's AAA rating.

In economic data: Eurozone's June loans to non-financial corporations 7.1% yr/yr (last 7.3%) and M3 Money Supply 9.2% yr/yr (expected 9.3%; last 8.9%) Germany's July ifo Business Climate Index 90.5 (expected 89.3; last 86.3). July Current Assessment 84.5 (expected 85.0; last 81.3) and Business Expectations 97.0 (expected 93.7; last 91.6) France's June jobseeker total 3.96 mln (last 4.17 mln)

---Equity Markets---

STOXX Europe 600: -0.4% Germany's DAX: -0.2%U.K.'s FTSE 100: -0.4% France's CAC 40: -0.5% Italy's FTSE MIB: -0.7% Spain's IBEX 35: -1.8%

08:32 ET

Market is Closed

[BRIEFING.COM] S&P futures vs fair value: +12.60. Nasdaq futures vs fair value: +81.10.

The S&P 500 futures trade 13 points, or 0.4%, above fair value.

Durable goods orders increased 7.3% in June (Briefing.com consensus +6.4%), and the prior month's increase was revised to 15.1% (from 15.8%). Excluding transportation, durable orders increased 3.3% (Briefing.com consensus +3.3%) to follow the prior month's revised 3.6% increase (from 4.0%).

07:56 ET

Market is Closed

[BRIEFING.COM] S&P futures vs fair value: +14.90. Nasdaq futures vs fair value: +99.60.

The S&P 500 futures trade 15 points, or 0.5%, above fair value to start the week, as investors await the coronavirus relief bill negotiated by the White House and Senate Republicans.

Reports indicate the bill will cost about $1 trillion, significantly less than what Democrats want, while Politico reported that GOP lawmakers intend on releasing the bill around 4:30 p.m. ET today, which would be after today's close. Related headlines could be announced throughout the day.

Separately, the mega-cap technology stocks are providing solid support for the futures trade after two straight weeks of mega-cap consolidation. On a related note, several of these big tech CEOs will testify before Congress on Wednesday regarding antitrust concerns.

On the data front, investors will receive Durable Goods Orders for June (Briefing.com consensus 6.4%) at 8:30 a.m. ET.

U.S. Treasuries trade little changed, while precious metals have extended their recent rally amid continued weakness in the dollar (93.78, -0.66, -0.7%). Gold futures are up 2.1% to $1937.40/ozt. The 2-yr yield is up one basis point to 0.15%, and the 10-yr yield is flat at 0.58%. WTI crude is up 0.3% to $41.43/bbl.

In U.S. Corporate news:

Moderna (MRNA 79.37, +6.16): +8.4% after being awarded up to $472 million from the Biomedical Advanced Research and Development Authority (BARDA) to develop its COVID-19 vaccine candidate.Amazon (AMZN 3059.00, +50.09): +1.7% amid today's mega-cap gains. On a related note, Telsey Advisory Group raised its AMZN price target to $3600 from $2800.Hasbro (HAS 74.00, -3.59): -4.6% after missing top and bottom-line estimates.

Reviewing overnight developments:

Equity indices in the Asia-Pacific region began the week on a mixed note. Japan's Nikkei: -0.2%, Hong Kong's Hang Seng: -0.4%, China's Shanghai Composite: +0.3%, India's Sensex: -0.5%, South Korea's Kospi: +0.8%, Australia's ASX All Ordinaries: +0.4%.In economic data:China's June Industrial Profit -12.8% YTD (last -19.3%)Japan's May Leading Index 78.4 (expected 79.3; last 77.7) and Coincident Indicator -6.7% m/m (last -5.5%)Hong Kong's June trade deficit HKD33.30 bln (last deficit of HKD13.70 bln). June Imports -7.1% m/m (last -12.3%) and Exports -1.3% m/m (last -7.4%)In news:U.S. officials entered the Chinese consulate in Houston shortly after the passage of Friday's deadline that was given to the Chinese diplomatic mission. China responded by seizing the U.S. consulate in Chengdu this morning.Reserve Bank of Australia Assistant Governor, Christopher Kent, said that the RBA is not considering new policy measures at this time.Major European indices trade in mixed fashion. STOXX Europe 600: -0.3%, Germany's DAX: +0.1%, U.K.'s FTSE 100: -0.3%, France's CAC 40: -0.4%, Italy's FTSE MIB: -0.5%, Spain's IBEX 35: -1.7%.In economic data:Eurozone's June loans to non-financial corporations 7.1% yr/yr (last 7.3%) and M3 Money Supply 9.2% yr/yr (expected 9.3%; last 8.9%)Germany's July ifo Business Climate Index 90.5 (expected 89.3; last 86.3). July Current Assessment 84.5 (expected 85.0; last 81.3) and Business Expectations 97.0 (expected 93.7; last 91.6)France's June jobseeker total 3.96 mln (last 4.17 mln)In news:Italy's Economy Minister, Roberto Gualtieri, reportedly warned about the potential for a funding crisis in the fall if states do not receive immediate access to loans. Bundesbank President, Jens Weidmann, said that using mutualized debt to help weaker states should be an exception. Fitch affirmed Greece's BB rating and the ESM's AAA rating.

07:25 ET

Market is Closed

[BRIEFING.COM] S&P futures vs fair value: +10.40. Nasdaq futures vs fair value: +81.50.

07:00 ET

Market is Closed

[BRIEFING.COM] S&P futures vs fair value: +13.10. Nasdaq futures vs fair value: +93.90.

07:00 ET

Market is Closed

[BRIEFING.COM] Nikkei...22716...-35.80...-0.20%. Hang Seng...24603...-102.10...-0.40%.

07:00 ET

Market is Closed

[BRIEFING.COM] FTSE...6113.61...-10.20...-0.20%. DAX...12877.15...+39.10...+0.30%.

16:20 ET

Dow -182.44 at 26469.89, Nasdaq -98.24 at 10363.26, S&P -20.03 at 3215.63

[BRIEFING.COM] The stock market ended the week in negative territory in a mostly broad-based decline. The S&P 500 fell 0.6%, the Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.7%, and the Nasdaq Composite fell 0.9%. The small-cap Russell 2000 underperformed with a 1.5% decline.

Ten of the 11 S&P 500 sectors closed lower, but the health care (-1.1%) and information technology (-1.2%) sectors were the only sectors to decline more than 1.0%. Note, the tech sector was down as much as 2.7% intraday, while the consumer discretionary sector gained 0.3% as shares of Amazon (AMZN 3008.91, +22.36, +0.8%) recovered an early 3.3% decline.

Intel (INTC 50.59, -9.81, -16.2%) did very little recovering, with shares falling 16% after the company announced a six-month delay in its next-generation 7nm chip technology. While disappointing for Intel investors, the news was welcomed by investors of Advanced Micro Devices (AMD 69.40, +9.83, +16.5%).

Other negative factors today included China ordering the U.S. to close its consulate in Chengdu in response to the U.S. ordering China to close its consulate in Houston and a delay in the Republican coronavirus relief bill until next week.

On a more positive note, new home sales surged 13.8% m/m in June to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 776,000 (Briefing.com consensus 680,000). That was the strongest pace of sales since July 2007 and higher than the pre-pandemic pace of 774,000 seen in January.

In other corporate news, Goldman Sachs (GS 201.47, -1.66, -0.8%) settled its 1MDB case for $3.9 billion, Verizon (VZ 56.85, +1.00, +1.8%) beat top and bottom-line estimates, American Express (AXP 95.33, -1.34, -1.4%) reported mixed quarterly results, and Walt Disney (DIS 117.61, -0.51, -0.4%) reportedly delayed several blockbuster movies by a year.

U.S. Treasuries finished little changed. The 2-yr yield declined one basis point to 0.14%, and the 10-yr yield was flat at 0.58%. Gold futures rose 0.4% to $1897.50/ozt -- its highest settlement price ever amid continued weakness in the U.S. Dollar Index (94.39, -0.30, -0.3%). WTI crude futures settled little changed at $41.08/bbl.

Reviewing Friday's economic data:

New home sales surged 13.8% m/m in June to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 776,000 (Briefing.com consensus 680,000). That was the strongest pace of sales since July 2007 and higher than the pre-pandemic pace of 774,000 seen in January. On a yr/yr basis, new home sales were up 13.7%.The key takeaway from the report is that sales activity in the new home market is quite healthy given the tight supply of existing homes for sale, low mortgage rates, pent-up demand, and an emerging, coronavirus-driven shift by city dwellers to suburban settings.

Looking ahead, investors will receive Durable Goods Orders for June on Monday.

urn:contentItem:60FN-SV41-JC8H-K05K-00000-00Briefing.com: Stock Market Update - 10:55 ET2020-07-27T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:29:47ZLexisNexisBriefing.com: Stock Market Update - 10:55 ET

Stock Market Update

Updated: 27-Jul-20

The market at 10:55 ET

Dow: +134.52...

Nasdaq: +122.97... S&P: +20.07...

NYSE Vol: 212.0 mln.. Adv: 1684.. Dec: 1155

Nasdaq Vol: 1.4 bln.. Adv: 1967.. Dec: 1214

Moving the Market

Sector Watch

-- Mega-caps lifts market higher in front of busy news week-- U.S. dollar continues to weaken, gold futures keep rallying -- Investors await coronavirus relief bill later today

Strong: Information Technology, Consumer Discretionary, Communication Services, Materials

Weak: Financials, Energy, Utilities

10:55 ET

Dow +134.52 at 26604.41, Nasdaq +122.97 at 10486.23, S&P +20.07 at 3235.7

[BRIEFING.COM] The S&P 500 continues to trade near session highs with a 0.6% gain. Today's advance comes in front of a jam-packed week of news.

Later today, Republicans are expected to unveil a $1 trillion coronavirus relief bill, so stay tuned for that. On Wednesday, the FOMC will release its latest policy directive and CEOs from some of the largest tech companies will testify before Congress regarding antitrust concerns.

Apple (AAPL 377.36, +6.87, +1.8%), Amazon (AMZN 3065.75, +56.84, +1.9%), and Alphabet (GOOG 1529.04, +17.17, +1.1%) will then report earnings after Thursday's close.

10:25 ET

Dow +136.82 at 26606.71, Nasdaq +118.71 at 10481.97, S&P +18.93 at 3234.56

[BRIEFING.COM] The S&P 500 continues to trade higher by 0.6%, while the Russell 2000 trades higher by 0.5%.

In corporate news, Moderna (MRNA 77.40, +4.19, +5.7%) announced it will receive an additional $472 million from the Biomedical Advanced Research and Development Authority (BARDA) to develop its COVID-19 vaccine candidate. MRNA shares are up 5%.

Separately, shares of Hasbro (HAS 72.55, -5.04, -6.5%) are down 6.5% after the company missed top and bottom-line estimates.

10:00 ET

Dow +106.38 at 26576.27, Nasdaq +135.54 at 10498.8, S&P +18.20 at 3233.83

[BRIEFING.COM] The S&P 500 is now up 0.6%, as the materials (+1.2%) and health care (+0.5%) sectors join the the mega-cap rally.

Apple (AAPL 377.94, +7.49, +2.0%) and Amazon (AMZN 3081.12, +73.98, +2.4%) are up 2.0% after the stocks spent the last two weeks in consolidation mode. On a related note, AAPL had its price target raised to $425 from $365 at JP Morgan, and AMZN had its price target raised to $3600 from $2800 at Telsey Advisory Group.

Separately, shares of Walgreens Boots Alliance (WBA 39.63, -0.88, -2.1%) are down 2% amid news that CEO Stefano Pessina will step down from the helm.

09:40 ET

Dow -30.93 at 26438.96, Nasdaq +93.21 at 10456.47, S&P +3.31 at 3218.94

[BRIEFING.COM] The major indices start the day mixed, with the Nasdaq Composite outperforming with a 0.9% gain. The S&P 500 is up 0.1%, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average is down 0.1%.

Looking at the S&P 500 sectors shows mixed results. The information technology (+0.7%), consumer discretionary (+0.6%), and communication services (+0.4%) sectors are among the early leaders amid relative strength in the mega-caps, while the financials (-1.2%) and energy (-1.1%) sectors are down more than 1.0%.

U.S. Treasuries trade near their flat lines. The 2-yr yield is flat at 0.14%, and the 10-yr yield is flat at 0.58%. Gold futures ($1928.30, +30.80, +1.7%) are trading above $1900/ozt, benefiting from a weak dollar (93.77, -0.67, -0.7%). WTI crude is down 0.9% to $40.93/bbl.

09:12 ET

Market is Closed

[BRIEFING.COM] S&P futures vs fair value: +10.60. Nasdaq futures vs fair value: +83.00.

The stock market is headed for a slightly higher start, as the S&P 500 futures trade 11 points, or 0.3%, above fair value ahead of an eventful week.

Apple (AAPL 374.94, +4.48, +1.2%), Amazon (AMZN 3063.98, +55.07, +1.8%), and Alphabet (GOOG 1524.00, +12.13, +0.8%) outperform in pre-market action ahead of their earnings reports on Thursday. There will be plenty of action before Thursday, though.

Senate Republicans are expected to unveil a $1 trillion coronavirus relief bill today, the FOMC will begin a two-day policy meeting on Tuesday, and the CEOs to some of the largest tech companies will head to Capitol Hill on Wednesday to address regulatory concerns.

08:51 ET

Market is Closed

[BRIEFING.COM] S&P futures vs fair value: +7.90. Nasdaq futures vs fair value: +67.50.

The S&P 500 futures trade eight points, or 0.3%, above fair value.

Equity indices in the Asia-Pacific region began the week on a mixed note. U.S. officials entered the Chinese consulate in Houston shortly after the passage of Friday's deadline that was given to the Chinese diplomatic mission. China responded by seizing the U.S. consulate in Chengdu this morning. Reserve Bank of Australia Assistant Governor, Christopher Kent, said that the RBA is not considering new policy measures at this time.

In economic data: China's June Industrial Profit -12.8% YTD (last -19.3%) Japan's May Leading Index 78.4 (expected 79.3; last 77.7) and Coincident Indicator -6.7% m/m (last -5.5%) Hong Kong's June trade deficit HKD33.30 bln (last deficit of HKD13.70 bln). June Imports -7.1% m/m (last -12.3%) and Exports -1.3% m/m (last -7.4%)

---Equity Markets---

Japan's Nikkei: -0.2% Hong Kong's Hang Seng: -0.4% China's Shanghai Composite: +0.3% India's Sensex: -0.5% South Korea's Kospi: +0.8% Australia's ASX All Ordinaries: +0.4%

Major European indices trade in negative territory. Italy's Economy Minister, Roberto Gualtieri, reportedly warned about the potential for a funding crisis in the fall if states do not receive immediate access to loans. Bundesbank President, Jens Weidmann, said that using mutualized debt to help weaker states should be an exception. Fitch affirmed Greece's BB rating and the ESM's AAA rating.

In economic data: Eurozone's June loans to non-financial corporations 7.1% yr/yr (last 7.3%) and M3 Money Supply 9.2% yr/yr (expected 9.3%; last 8.9%) Germany's July ifo Business Climate Index 90.5 (expected 89.3; last 86.3). July Current Assessment 84.5 (expected 85.0; last 81.3) and Business Expectations 97.0 (expected 93.7; last 91.6) France's June jobseeker total 3.96 mln (last 4.17 mln)

---Equity Markets---

STOXX Europe 600: -0.4% Germany's DAX: -0.2%U.K.'s FTSE 100: -0.4% France's CAC 40: -0.5% Italy's FTSE MIB: -0.7% Spain's IBEX 35: -1.8%

08:32 ET

Market is Closed

[BRIEFING.COM] S&P futures vs fair value: +12.60. Nasdaq futures vs fair value: +81.10.

The S&P 500 futures trade 13 points, or 0.4%, above fair value.

Durable goods orders increased 7.3% in June (Briefing.com consensus +6.4%), and the prior month's increase was revised to 15.1% (from 15.8%). Excluding transportation, durable orders increased 3.3% (Briefing.com consensus +3.3%) to follow the prior month's revised 3.6% increase (from 4.0%).

07:56 ET

Market is Closed

[BRIEFING.COM] S&P futures vs fair value: +14.90. Nasdaq futures vs fair value: +99.60.

The S&P 500 futures trade 15 points, or 0.5%, above fair value to start the week, as investors await the coronavirus relief bill negotiated by the White House and Senate Republicans.

Reports indicate the bill will cost about $1 trillion, significantly less than what Democrats want, while Politico reported that GOP lawmakers intend on releasing the bill around 4:30 p.m. ET today, which would be after today's close. Related headlines could be announced throughout the day.

Separately, the mega-cap technology stocks are providing solid support for the futures trade after two straight weeks of mega-cap consolidation. On a related note, several of these big tech CEOs will testify before Congress on Wednesday regarding antitrust concerns.

On the data front, investors will receive Durable Goods Orders for June (Briefing.com consensus 6.4%) at 8:30 a.m. ET.

U.S. Treasuries trade little changed, while precious metals have extended their recent rally amid continued weakness in the dollar (93.78, -0.66, -0.7%). Gold futures are up 2.1% to $1937.40/ozt. The 2-yr yield is up one basis point to 0.15%, and the 10-yr yield is flat at 0.58%. WTI crude is up 0.3% to $41.43/bbl.

In U.S. Corporate news:

Moderna (MRNA 79.37, +6.16): +8.4% after being awarded up to $472 million from the Biomedical Advanced Research and Development Authority (BARDA) to develop its COVID-19 vaccine candidate.Amazon (AMZN 3059.00, +50.09): +1.7% amid today's mega-cap gains. On a related note, Telsey Advisory Group raised its AMZN price target to $3600 from $2800.Hasbro (HAS 74.00, -3.59): -4.6% after missing top and bottom-line estimates.

Reviewing overnight developments:

Equity indices in the Asia-Pacific region began the week on a mixed note. Japan's Nikkei: -0.2%, Hong Kong's Hang Seng: -0.4%, China's Shanghai Composite: +0.3%, India's Sensex: -0.5%, South Korea's Kospi: +0.8%, Australia's ASX All Ordinaries: +0.4%.In economic data:China's June Industrial Profit -12.8% YTD (last -19.3%)Japan's May Leading Index 78.4 (expected 79.3; last 77.7) and Coincident Indicator -6.7% m/m (last -5.5%)Hong Kong's June trade deficit HKD33.30 bln (last deficit of HKD13.70 bln). June Imports -7.1% m/m (last -12.3%) and Exports -1.3% m/m (last -7.4%)In news:U.S. officials entered the Chinese consulate in Houston shortly after the passage of Friday's deadline that was given to the Chinese diplomatic mission. China responded by seizing the U.S. consulate in Chengdu this morning.Reserve Bank of Australia Assistant Governor, Christopher Kent, said that the RBA is not considering new policy measures at this time.Major European indices trade in mixed fashion. STOXX Europe 600: -0.3%, Germany's DAX: +0.1%, U.K.'s FTSE 100: -0.3%, France's CAC 40: -0.4%, Italy's FTSE MIB: -0.5%, Spain's IBEX 35: -1.7%.In economic data:Eurozone's June loans to non-financial corporations 7.1% yr/yr (last 7.3%) and M3 Money Supply 9.2% yr/yr (expected 9.3%; last 8.9%)Germany's July ifo Business Climate Index 90.5 (expected 89.3; last 86.3). July Current Assessment 84.5 (expected 85.0; last 81.3) and Business Expectations 97.0 (expected 93.7; last 91.6)France's June jobseeker total 3.96 mln (last 4.17 mln)In news:Italy's Economy Minister, Roberto Gualtieri, reportedly warned about the potential for a funding crisis in the fall if states do not receive immediate access to loans. Bundesbank President, Jens Weidmann, said that using mutualized debt to help weaker states should be an exception. Fitch affirmed Greece's BB rating and the ESM's AAA rating.

07:25 ET

Market is Closed

[BRIEFING.COM] S&P futures vs fair value: +10.40. Nasdaq futures vs fair value: +81.50.

07:00 ET

Market is Closed

[BRIEFING.COM] S&P futures vs fair value: +13.10. Nasdaq futures vs fair value: +93.90.

07:00 ET

Market is Closed

[BRIEFING.COM] Nikkei...22716...-35.80...-0.20%. Hang Seng...24603...-102.10...-0.40%.

07:00 ET

Market is Closed

[BRIEFING.COM] FTSE...6113.61...-10.20...-0.20%. DAX...12877.15...+39.10...+0.30%.

16:20 ET

Dow -182.44 at 26469.89, Nasdaq -98.24 at 10363.26, S&P -20.03 at 3215.63

[BRIEFING.COM] The stock market ended the week in negative territory in a mostly broad-based decline. The S&P 500 fell 0.6%, the Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.7%, and the Nasdaq Composite fell 0.9%. The small-cap Russell 2000 underperformed with a 1.5% decline.

Ten of the 11 S&P 500 sectors closed lower, but the health care (-1.1%) and information technology (-1.2%) sectors were the only sectors to decline more than 1.0%. Note, the tech sector was down as much as 2.7% intraday, while the consumer discretionary sector gained 0.3% as shares of Amazon (AMZN 3008.91, +22.36, +0.8%) recovered an early 3.3% decline.

Intel (INTC 50.59, -9.81, -16.2%) did very little recovering, with shares falling 16% after the company announced a six-month delay in its next-generation 7nm chip technology. While disappointing for Intel investors, the news was welcomed by investors of Advanced Micro Devices (AMD 69.40, +9.83, +16.5%).

Other negative factors today included China ordering the U.S. to close its consulate in Chengdu in response to the U.S. ordering China to close its consulate in Houston and a delay in the Republican coronavirus relief bill until next week.

On a more positive note, new home sales surged 13.8% m/m in June to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 776,000 (Briefing.com consensus 680,000). That was the strongest pace of sales since July 2007 and higher than the pre-pandemic pace of 774,000 seen in January.

In other corporate news, Goldman Sachs (GS 201.47, -1.66, -0.8%) settled its 1MDB case for $3.9 billion, Verizon (VZ 56.85, +1.00, +1.8%) beat top and bottom-line estimates, American Express (AXP 95.33, -1.34, -1.4%) reported mixed quarterly results, and Walt Disney (DIS 117.61, -0.51, -0.4%) reportedly delayed several blockbuster movies by a year.

U.S. Treasuries finished little changed. The 2-yr yield declined one basis point to 0.14%, and the 10-yr yield was flat at 0.58%. Gold futures rose 0.4% to $1897.50/ozt -- its highest settlement price ever amid continued weakness in the U.S. Dollar Index (94.39, -0.30, -0.3%). WTI crude futures settled little changed at $41.08/bbl.

Reviewing Friday's economic data:

New home sales surged 13.8% m/m in June to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 776,000 (Briefing.com consensus 680,000). That was the strongest pace of sales since July 2007 and higher than the pre-pandemic pace of 774,000 seen in January. On a yr/yr basis, new home sales were up 13.7%.The key takeaway from the report is that sales activity in the new home market is quite healthy given the tight supply of existing homes for sale, low mortgage rates, pent-up demand, and an emerging, coronavirus-driven shift by city dwellers to suburban settings.

Looking ahead, investors will receive Durable Goods Orders for June on Monday.

urn:contentItem:5WN0-J2W1-JC8H-K3YP-00000-00Briefing.com: Stock Market Update - 10:55 ET2019-07-24T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:29:47ZLexisNexisBriefing.com: Stock Market Update - 10:55 ET

Stock Market Update

Updated: 24-Jul-19

The market at 10:55 ET

Dow: -135.83...

Nasdaq: -11.98... S&P: +1.62...

NYSE Vol: 167.9 mln.. Adv: 1733.. Dec: 992

Nasdaq Vol: 549.8 mln.. Adv: 1636.. Dec: 1186

Moving the Market

Sector Watch

Wall Street climbs off opening lowsRelative strength in UPS (UPS) and the semiconductor stocks following upbeat earnings resultsCaterpillar (CAT), Boeing (BA), and mega-cap tech underperformDoJ launches broad antitrust review of market-leading online platforms

Strong: Industrials, Information Technology, Energy

Weak: Health Care, Utilities

10:55 ET

Dow -135.83 at 27213.36, Nasdaq -11.98 at 8239.43, S&P +1.62 at 3007.09

[BRIEFING.COM] The S&P 500 currently trades higher 0.1% after beginning the day on a lower note. The outperformance in several industrial companies and the semiconductor stocks has contributed to the positive disposition.

Like the broader market, the industrials sector (+0.3%) began the day lower amid weakness in shares of Boeing (BA 367.34, -5.69, -1.5%) and Caterpillar (CAT 132.38, -5.67, -4.1%) after disappointing investors with results and/or guidance. UPS (UPS 114.00, +8.73, +8.3%) and Northrop Grumman (NOC 337.20, +13.22, +4.1%), however, have provided strong support for the sector after pleasing investors with their results.

Similarly, the Philadelphia Semiconductor Index is up 2.5%, rising on the back of solid results from Texas Instruments (TXN 127.99, +7.92, +6.6%). The PHLX is now up a staggering 40% this year.

10:40 ET

Dow -64.20 at 27284.99, Nasdaq +23.24 at 8274.65, S&P +5.19 at 3010.66

[BRIEFING.COM] Commodities are higher (+0.5% at 79.92 as measured by the Bloomberg Commodity Index)Dollar index is lower (-0.1% at 97.6160)Looking at energy:Aug WTI crude oil futures are now +$0.75 (+1.3%) at $57.52/barrelEIA petroleum data for the week ended July 19- huge draw in oilCrude oil inventories had a draw of 10.8 mln from the prior weekPrior week showed a draw of 3.1 mlnGasoline Inventories had a draw of 0.2 mln barrelPrior week had a build of 3.6 mln barrelDistillate Inventories had a build of 0.6 mlnPrior week had a build of 5.7 mlnEIA reported U.S. oil production fell 700K barrels per day (bpd) to 11.3 mln bpd, a massive reduction. Recent storm Barry plays some part in the reported data, but this really does seem to be a huge reduction..In other energy, Aug natural gas is -$0.06 (-2.5%) at $2.24/MMBtuMoving on to metals:Aug gold is currently +$2.85 (+0.2%) at $1424.55/oz, while Jul silver is +$0.13 (+0.8%) at $16.61/ozSept copper is now +$0.02 (+0.6%) at $2.72/lb ..NYSE Adv/Dec 1800/911. ..NASDAQ Adv/Dec 1719/1095.

10:00 ET

Dow -80.60 at 27268.59, Nasdaq +3.12 at 8254.53, S&P +0.18 at 3005.65

[BRIEFING.COM] The S&P 500 has marched back to its flat line, while the Russell 2000 trades lower by x%.

Just in, New Home Sales in June hit an annualized rate of 646,000, coming in below the Briefing.com consensus of 660,000. The May reading was revised to 604,000 (from 626,000).

09:45 ET

Dow -139.01 at 27210.18, Nasdaq -6.58 at 8244.83, S&P -2.97 at 3002.5

[BRIEFING.COM] The stock market begins the day modestly lower amid weakness in Caterpillar (CAT 129.24, -8.89, -6.4%), Boeing (BA 367.44, -5.80, -1.6%), and mega-cap tech stocks. The S&P 500 is down 0.1%, the Dow Jones Industrial Average is down 0.5%, and the Nasdaq composite is down 0.1%.

An early look at the S&P 500 sectors shows industrials (-0.1%) recovering some its opening losses as UPS (UPS 114.00, +8.71, +8.0%) helps offset losses from Caterpillar and Boeing following their earnings reports. Health care (-0.9%) is an early laggard, while energy (+0.4%) outperforms.

Separately, Facebook (FB 199.30, -3.09, -1.5%), Alphabet (GOOG 1131.90, -14.31, -1.3%), and Amazon (AMZN 1974.59, -19.90, -1.0%) are each down at least 1.0% after the DoJ launched an antitrust probe into the leading online platforms.

U.S. Treasuries are slightly higher, pushing yields lower. The 2-yr yield and the 10-yr yield are down two basis points each to 1.81% and 2.05%, respectively. The U.S. Dollar Index is down 0.1% to 97.63. WTI crude is up 0.3% to $56.91/bbl.

09:15 ET

Market is Closed

[BRIEFING.COM] S&P futures vs fair value: -7.60. Nasdaq futures vs fair value: -24.50.

Wall Street is headed for a lower start in a busy morning in news that has reined in some of yesterday's enthusiasm. The S&P 500 futures trade eight points, or 0.3%, below fair value.

Alphabet (GOOG 1134.35, -11.86, -1.0%), Amazon (AMZN 1970.00, -24.49, -1.2%), and Facebook (FB 198.50, -3.86, -1.9%) are under pressure this morning after the DoJ announced that it will conduct a broad antitrust review of market-leading online platforms. On a related note, the FTC confirmed that Facebook will pay $5 billion for its privacy mishaps.

Elsewhere, shares of Caterpillar (CAT 131.20, -6.60, -4.8%) are getting hit in pre-market after the Dow component missed earnings estimates and lowered its full-year EPS guidance. Fellow Dow components Visa (V 180.21, -0.69, -0.4%) and Boeing (BA 370.89, -2.18, -0.6%) are also down following their results.

Overseas, the slowdown in the eurozone region has persisted, evidenced by the weaker-than-expected flash Manufacturing PMI readings for July. The eurozone reading declined to 46.4 from 47.6. A level below 50.0 denotes a contraction.

08:50 ET

Market is Closed

[BRIEFING.COM] S&P futures vs fair value: -7.10. Nasdaq futures vs fair value: -20.40.

The S&P 500 futures trade seven points, or 0.2%, below fair value.

Equity indices in the Asia-Pacific region ended the midweek session on a mixed note. People's Bank of China Governor, Yi Gang, said that the central bank does not intend to follow the Fed with a rate cut of its own. Meanwhile, Westpac expects that the Reserve Bank of Australia will lower its cash rate in October and February. Japan threatened to remove South Korea from a list of countries that face minimum export restrictions. Nissan will reportedly fire more than 10,000 workers.

In economic data: Japan's May Leading Index 94.9 (expected 95.2; last 95.9) and flash July Manufacturing PMI 49.6 (expected 49.7; last 49.3). Australia's flash July Manufacturing PMI 51.4 (last 52.0) and flash Services PMI 51.9 (last 52.6). New Zealand's June trade surplus NZD365 mln (expected surplus of NZD100 mln; last surplus of NZD175 mln).

---Equity Markets---

Japan's Nikkei: +0.4% Hong Kong's Hang Seng: +0.2% China's Shanghai Composite: +0.8% India's Sensex: -0.4% South Korea's Kospi: -0.9% Australia's ASX All Ordinaries: +0.7%

Major European indices are mixed. The latest flash Manufacturing PMI readings from France and Germany showed another decrease with Germany's flash Manufacturing PMI sliding to 43.1, a level not seen since the summer of 2012 when the region was grappling with a financial crisis. Incoming British Prime Minister Boris Johnson said that all members of his cabinet must allow for the possibility of a no-deal Brexit. Deutsche Bank is down 2.5% after reporting its largest loss in eleven years.

In economic data: Eurozone's flash July Manufacturing PMI 46.4 (expected 47.6; last 47.6) and flash Services PMI 53.3, as expected (last 53.6). June M3 Money Supply +4.5% yr/yr (expected 4.6%; last 4.8%) and Private Sector Loans +3.3% yr/yr (expected 3.2%; last 3.3%). Germany's flash July Manufacturing PMI 43.1 (expected 45.1; last 45.0) and flash Services PMI 55.4 (expected 55.3; last 55.8). France's flash July Manufacturing PMI 50.0 (expected 51.6; last 51.9) and Services PMI 52.2 (expected 52.7; last 52.9). July Business Survey 101 (expected 102; last 102). Swiss July ZEW Expectations -24.0 (last -30.0)

---Equity Markets---

STOXX Europe 600: -0.1%Germany's DAX: +0.3% U.K.'s FTSE 100: -0.8% France's CAC 40: -0.4% Italy's FTSE MIB: +0.3% Spain's IBEX 35: +0.3%

08:29 ET

Market is Closed

[BRIEFING.COM] S&P futures vs fair value: -6.40. Nasdaq futures vs fair value: -16.30.

The S&P 500 futures trade six points, or 0.2%, below fair value.

Treasury Secretary Mnuchin recently had wide-ranging interview with CNBC. Regarding the planned trade talks with China, he said he will depart for Beijing with USTR Lighthizer on Monday, and negotiations will be held on Tuesday and Wednesday. Separately, he said the DoJ should look into Amazon's (AMZN 1973.00, -21.49, -1.1%) practices.

In other earnings news, ChipotleMexican Grill (CMG 762.34, +22.74, +3.1%) and Snap (SNAP 16.48, +1.65, +11.3%) have impressed investors with upbeat results and guidance. Telsey Advisory Group and Maxim Group raised their CMG price targets to $750 and $670, respectively. Snap was upgraded to Neutral from Sell at UBS and Buy from Hold at Summit Insights.

08:00 ET

Market is Closed

[BRIEFING.COM] S&P futures vs fair value: -7.90. Nasdaq futures vs fair value: -17.90.

U.S. equity futures have been weighed down this morning by the big technology stocks amid continued regulatory scrutiny. The S&P 500 futures trade eight points, or 0.3%, below fair value.

The Department of Justice announced yesterday that it will conduct a broad antitrust review of the "market-leading online platforms." Big tech scrutiny is nothing new, but the latest action confirms serious efforts to check the influence of big tech companies. The regulatory overhang has weighed on shares of Alphabet (GOOG 1134.00, -12.21, -1.1%), Facebook (FB 199.55, -2.81, -1.4%), and Amazon (AMZN 1976.60, -17.89, -0.9%) in pre-market action.

In earnings news, Dow components Visa (V 180.20, -0.70, -0.4%), Boeing (BA 370.50, -2.57, -0.7%), and Caterpillar (CAT 133.49, -4.61, -3.3%) were some blue-chip companies to report since yesterday's close. Shares of Caterpillar are getting hit following disappointing results and guidance, while shares of Boeing slip after the company continues to not provide full-year guidance.

Elsewhere, the eurozone flash July Manufacturing PMI declined below expectations, coming in at 46.4, amid weakness in Germany. A reading below 50.0 denotes a contraction. In U.S. data, investors will receive New Home Sales for June (Briefing.com consensus 660,000) at 10:00 a.m. ET. The weekly MBA Mortgage Applications Index declined 1.9% following a 1.1% decline in the prior week.

U.S. Treasuries haven't reflected too much concern about the eurozone slowdown, as yields are little changed. The 2-yr yield is down two basis points to 1.81%, and the 10-yr yield is down one basis point to 2.06%. The U.S. Dollar Index is down 0.1% to 97.61. WTI crude is up 0.4% to $56.99/bbl.

In U.S. Corporate news:

Boeing (BA 370.50, -2.57): -0.7% despite beating top and bottom-line estimates. Boeing reported an EPS loss, which was expected, but the company continues to not provide full-year guidance. Caterpillar (CAT 133.49, -4.61): -3.3% after missing earnings expectations and lowering its FY19 EPS guidance. Visa (V 180.20, -0.70): -0.4% despite beating top and bottom-line estimates and slightly raising its FY19 EPS guidance. Texas Instruments (TXN 126.33, +6.26): +5.2% after beating top and bottom-line estimates. AT&T (T 31.53, -0.56): -1.8% despite releasing in-line results and raising its free cash flow guidance. UPS (UPS 108.00, +2.73): +2.6% after beating profit expectations.

Reviewing overnight developments:

Equity indices in the Asia-Pacific region ended the midweek session on a mixed note. Japan's Nikkei +0.4%, Hong Kong's Hang Seng +0.2%, China's Shanghai Composite +0.8%, India's Sensex -0.4%, South Korea's Kospi -0.9%, Australia's ASX All Ordinaries +0.7%.In economic data:Japan's May Leading Index 94.9 (expected 95.2; last 95.9) and flash July Manufacturing PMI 49.6 (expected 49.7; last 49.3).Australia's flash July Manufacturing PMI 51.4 (last 52.0) and flash Services PMI 51.9 (last 52.6).New Zealand's June trade surplus NZD365 mln (expected surplus of NZD100 mln; last surplus of NZD175 mln).In news: People's Bank of China Governor, Yi Gang, said that the central bank does not intend to follow the Fed with a rate cut of its own.Meanwhile, Westpac expects that the Reserve Bank of Australia will lower its cash rate in October and February. Japan threatened to remove South Korea from a list of countries that face minimum export restrictions. Nissan will reportedly fire more than 10,000 workers.Major European indices are mixed. STOXX Europe 600 UNCH, Germany's DAX +0.4%, U.K.'s FTSE 100 -1.0%, France's CAC 40 -0.3%, Italy's FTSE MIB +0.4%, Spain's IBEX 35 +0.3%.In economic data:Eurozone's flash July Manufacturing PMI 46.4 (expected 47.6; last 47.6) and flash Services PMI 53.3, as expected (last 53.6). June M3 Money Supply +4.5% yr/yr (expected 4.6%; last 4.8%) and Private Sector Loans +3.3% yr/yr (expected 3.2%; last 3.3%).Germany's flash July Manufacturing PMI 43.1 (expected 45.1; last 45.0) and flash Services PMI 55.4 (expected 55.3; last 55.8).France's flash July Manufacturing PMI 50.0 (expected 51.6; last 51.9) and Services PMI 52.2 (expected 52.7; last 52.9). July Business Survey 101 (expected 102; last 102).Swiss July ZEW Expectations -24.0 (last -30.0)In news:The latest flash Manufacturing PMI readings from France and Germany showed another decrease with Germany's flash Manufacturing PMI sliding to 43.1, a level not seen since the summer of 2012 when the region was grappling with a financial crisis. Incoming British Prime Minister Boris Johnson said that all members of his cabinet must allow for the possibility of a no-deal Brexit.Deutsche Bank is down 2.5% after reporting its largest loss in eleven years.

07:27 ET

Market is Closed

[BRIEFING.COM] S&P futures vs fair value: -6.10. Nasdaq futures vs fair value: -17.60.

05:51 ET

Market is Closed

[BRIEFING.COM] S&P futures vs fair value: -11.60. Nasdaq futures vs fair value: -42.40.

05:51 ET

Market is Closed

[BRIEFING.COM] Nikkei...21709.57...+88.70...+0.40%. Hang Seng...28524.04...+57.60...+0.20%.

05:51 ET

Market is Closed

[BRIEFING.COM] FTSE...7484.95...-71.90...-1.00%. DAX...12504.5...+13.80...+0.10%.

16:15 ET

Dow +177.29 at 27349.19, Nasdaq +47.27 at 8251.41, S&P +20.44 at 3005.47

[BRIEFING.COM] The S&P 500 increased 0.7% on Tuesday, bolstered by encouraging trade news and positive earnings reports from widely-held companies. The Dow Jones Industrial Average (+0.7%), Nasdaq Composite (+0.6%), and Russell 2000 (+0.7%) advanced in-line with the benchmark index.

It had been a tight-ranged session for a good part of the day despite positive earnings results and guidance from a diversified group of companies like Coca-Cola (KO 54.33, +3.11, +6.1%), United Technologies (UTX 134.94, +1.99, +1.5%), Sherwin-Williams (SHW 490.23, +35.64, +7.8%), and Biogen (BIIB 243.88, +11.40, +4.9%). Travelers (TRV 147.50, -2.21, -1.5%), however, did come up short of expectations.

Unsurprisingly, a positive trade headline helped energize the slow-moving market. Bloomberg reported that USTR Lighthizer and other senior officials will head to China next week to continue trade talks from Monday to Wednesday. Although this possibility had been reported earlier and many high-level talks in the past have yielded little progress, the good mood in the market flowing from earnings seemed to sway the market.

The news pushed the S&P 500 back above the 3000 level, where it would stay above on a closing basis. Ten of the 11 S&P 500 sectors finished higher, led by the trade-sensitive materials (+2.0%) and industrials (+1.2%) sectors. The utilities sector was the lone holdout, finishing lower by 0.6%.

Qualcomm (QCOM 74.12, -1.83, -2.4%) was also left out of the advance after The Wall Street Journal reported that Apple (AAPL 208.84, +1.62, +0.8%) is considering buying Intel's (INTC 51.75, +0.40, +0.8%) smartphone-modem chip business for around $1 billion. The Philadelphia Semiconductor Index finished up 1.2%.

Separately, Congress reached a deal to increase the budget deficit and suspend the debt ceiling for two years. The news provided some relief for investors, but market reaction was mostly muted as the dilemma never appeared to hinder the market beforehand and it was reported yesterday that a deal was close.

U.S. Treasuries finished on a lower note, pushing yields higher across the curve. The 2-yr yield increased two basis points to 1.83%, and the 10-yr yield increased three basis points to 2.07%. The U.S. Dollar Index advanced 0.5% to 97.74, helped by some weakness in the euro. WTI crude rose 0.9% to $56.72/bbl.

Reviewing Tuesday's economic data, which included Existing Home Sales for June and the FHFA Housing Market Index for May:

Existing home sales decreased 1.7% month-over-month in June to a seasonally-adjusted annual rate of 5.27 million (Briefing.com consensus 5.30 million) from an upwardly revised 5.36 million (from 5.34 million) in May. Total sales were 2.2% lower than the same period a year ago.The key takeaway from the report is that the drop in mortgage rates has failed to spur a meaningful pickup in existing home sales, which continue to be constrained by the lack of available supply at lower price points.The FHFA Housing Price Index for May increased 0.1% after advancing 0.4% in June.

Looking ahead, investors will receive New Home Sales for June and the weekly MBA Mortgage Applications Index on Wednesday.
